You bag what you want yourself while you wait in line then pay at the register. This makes the line move a lot quicker than it would if the cashiers had to bag everything for you. The sourdough baguettes made for excellent sandwiches for our plane ride home. 

I wish I'd tried their little pizzas or pastries. Maybe next time.
author: Ana R.

description:
A daughter cooperative of Berkeley's Cheeseboard Collective- and a member of a larger collective that supports and coordinates the establishment of new Bay Area cooperative bakeries- Arizmendi is a pioneer in the indie eating scene. It stands at the forefront of the Bay Area's movements for environmentally-conscious food and for honest, democratic, "equal and positive" workspaces.

Interestingly, my journey to this Arizmendi location began at the end of lunch at Cheeseboard Pizza one day. I finished my slice (Roma tomatoes, mozzarella and French feta cheese, lemon juice, lemon zest, olive oil and cilantro) and immediately began to consider what I wanted to eat next. It was not that I was still hungry: the pizza was just so palatable, so filling, that I didn't know what possibly could appropriately follow.

To see if any establishment could match the quality of my beloved Cheeseboard, I decided to visit one of the younger bakery cooperatives I had read so much about, and selected the Valencia location because it's the youngest. 

Upon arriving at around 3:15pm, I found the bakery relatively quiet, but was greeted warmly by the counter person. The wall of windows topped with hoppers, the high ceilings, and the (basically) open floor plan really impressed me. Such comfortable features are common in more spacious locations like Berkeley but come as a pleasant surprise on busier urban streets. I purchased a couple of vegan mint chocolate chip cookies and packed them away. Benevolent and probably very satisfied with his position as a worker-owner, the counter person wished me farewell with a grin, and returned to joking around with the present members of the collective.

I could not stop thinking about these beautiful vegan cookies, which had been showcased from behind clear glass doors in appealing wooden shelving units, so I devoured one while walking to meet a friend for dinner: a fantastic appetizer indeed! Ten minutes after my purchase, it still tasted like it had just come out of the oven. True to my expectations, it tasted impeccably.

Just a couple of blocks from the BART station at 16th and Mission, this Arizmendi Bakery is accessible. With each cookie at $2 and each slice of pizza at $2.50, it is affordable. As a workers' collective, it's worth the consistent support of anyone who appreciates responsible business practices, organic ingredients, and really excellent fresh food. 

You can read more about the Arizmendi Association of Cooperatives at http://ow.ly/gGREe.
author: Brian C.

description:
I kept on hearing about how amazing this place was (the sunset one, not this one). So, I went with a friend to check out this new venue and tried the currant scone:

- Starbucks's scone is WAY better! It was 4PM and the scone was dry, brittle, no moisture at all, no buttery flavor. It was exceptionally dull. I had to dunk it into my hot beverage to get some moisture out of it. 

The place doesn't have much seating either (around 4 tables) so we had to eat standing up spilling crumbs everywhere.

I also sampled their "pizza" which tasted more like seasoned bread as there wasn't much toppings. 

No moisture gooeyness in their pastries , no seating, and apparently Sunset Arizmendi  is WAY better (as per my friend's comment who I went with) So, now I'm really disappointed as apparently they're not consistent with the other store with the same name :( 

Now I *really* want to try the Arizmendi in Sunset. I want to taste the perfect scone.
author: Kathy S.

description: I stopped in for breakfast earlier this week. I was hoping they'd have breakfast sandwiches, but alas they do not. Or they didn't at 7 am. I went with the vegan banana nut muffin - not because I'm vegan, but because it looked delicious. And it was! I also got a corn cherry scone, which tasted less like a scone and more like the best cornbread you've ever had! I also dunked my banana nut muffin in some of the vanilla yogurt they sell. Nice breakfast - and I will be back to try more of their baked goods and the pizza!
author: David B.

description: This place is so damn good. Same as cheeseboard with the trip across the bay. Highly recommend
author: Dave C.

description:
How to get the most of this place:

1. For bread and rolls, show up early and their core breads will be warm and delicious. You can smell the fresh bread walking down the street. 
The best part about the morning too is that you can see them making all the breads for the day.

2. For pizza, come for lunch and enjoy with a friend. The atmosphere smells like heaven...and it's a good price

3. For their daily special breads and rolls, they aren't always ready first thing in the morning....but everything from multi-grain to pumpkin and they are worth coming in for.

Eat up San Francisco and support this local Co-op!
author: Patrick D.

description:
I haven't had any of their baked goods yet, but their pizza is unbelievable. The day I went, they had a pizza with baby bok choy and some kind of ginger vinaigrette. It was delicious. 
They tend to be crowded on Sunday afternoons, which is the only time I can go, so it can be hard to get a table.
I also love their whole business model. They're community-focused, sustainable and responsible. Wish I lived closer! Can't wait to go back and have a muffin or something.
author: Cami J.

description:
Excellent pizza love all the kinds I've tried so far . Bread is fresh and delicious pecan rolls are to die for !
I wish they would update their website it would be nice to know what pizza of the day is !
author: lyn m.

description:
I'm in love with this delicious bakery, for many reasons.  It's completely self serve (minus coffee) and the line isn't outrageous like at tartine.  Less of a hipster hang out spot so you can get your food in a normal/acceptable amount of time.

So far I've only tried 2 things, but would rate them 5 stars. SO GOOD.

Brioche Roll - yes please

scones - so flavorful and moist. this is how a scone should taste!!!

will definitely be back to try everything else very very soon. Happy camper to have found this place.
author: Melody T.

description:
If it's selection you want, this is not your jam. If it's creative, delicious, slathered-in-olive-oil you want, you really must top by.

The pizza is amazing. You just kind of have to let go and trust the chef (esp since you don't have a choice). It's an adventure. They also give you a tiny extra sliver of pizza with every order, which I totally love! It's like a side dish, but it's just more pizza. When my fiance and I go, we order separately so that they'll give us 2 extra slivers instead of one. 

The seating leaves something to be desired, and there's often a line. But no worries. Just come here for pizza, not a relaxing sit-down.
author: Vanessa C.

description: After going to their inner Richmond location, getting there 5 minutes before they close and being told that they are out of pizza, we decided to go to this one, since it closes an hour later and is only 10 minutes away. To make sure they weren't out of pizza, we called, but no one answered, so we just decided to give it a try since we didn't think they'd be out of it an hour before closing. Well, little did we know. We got there at 6:10, 50 minutes before they close, and they tell us they sold all of their pizza already. 50 MINUTES BEFORE CLOSING!!!! Why would a place that's known for its pizza make so little of it that they'd run out an hour before closing??? Seems like they don't really care about their customers and have some lazy workers who don't even bother to answer the phone. I don't think I'll be coming to any of their bakeries ever again :(
author: Mariya B.

description:
I'd heard about their other location in the Sunset, but was cruising through the Mission and was pleasantly surprised to find this one!  I'm a carb lover so even though I was full for lunch, I picked up a "chocolate thing" (a brioche with chocolate baked into it) and a lemon raspberry tea cake to take home.  The chocolate thing was awesome.  Nice flaky consistency, just the right amount of sweetness/buttery flavor, and big chunks of chocolate.  And the lemon raspberrry tea cake was spot on too...  soooo delicious!

Came back a week later for the pizza.  It was the spinach with kalamata olives, feta cheese, garlic oil, and parmesan.  A little oily for me, but it was pretty good.  However, I have to say that I like the pizza at The Cheeseboard in Berkeley better.

All in all, another great place in the Mission!
author: Jeff C.

description:
This place is the number one reason I can't move to San Francisco; unless I go out of my way to hit every hill and never take any sort of transportation besides my feet. On my first visit, I grabbed two vegan options: blueberry scone and poppy seed muffin. I thought I'd save those for a couples of bfasts, but once I took a bite of each, there was no holding back. I stopped by a second time and got the chocolate thing, mint chocolate chip cookie, corn blueberry muffin, wheat free vanilla raisin scone, and rosemary sourdough. I wasn't even halfway home (only 7 block walk) when I ate at least half of each bakery item. So ridiculously delicious! 

The scones were definitely my favorites, but honestly, everything was just sweet enough and had really great textures.
author: Amy H.

description: Dried out Challah bread- what a crime!!  I've been spoiled by east coast bakeries, so I'm a Challah bread snob. One day later and I tearfully tossed out my loaf of dried out stale bread. Who makes Challah bread that becomes stale within a day? The delicious lavender shortbread cookie almost makes me want to return,  but there must be better in the city.
author: Ritu K.

description:
Every thing I've tried from Arizmendi so far - vegan lemon poppy seed muffin, the blueberry corn muffin, cheese rolls, and the currant scones, have been absolutely delicious. I love a fresh warm baked good in the morning (who doesn't?!) and this place does it right. My only complaint is the coffee sizes are a little small.

I might be a little biased, as this place is right down the street from me and has quickly become my go-to breakfast stop, but this bakery is heavenly.
author: Rachel M.

description:
For someone who is constantly plagued by choice, not having one for pizza flavors is great.

This pizza style is similar to the Cheeseboard collective in Berkeley, however the dough is a littler thicker.  Great price for pizza, and in a wonderful area of the Mission.

Also, the scones and pastries are delicious as well.  

Tip: put honey on the pizza.
author: Adele Z.

description:
Before there were hipsters, there were hippies... from Berkeley of course, where I used to trek to the cooperative know as Cheeseboard, and where the first ingredient in everything was love. (and still is) After that co-op came 2 and now a 3rd Arizmendi, named after a Basque priest and cooperatives organizer, happily near my place in the Mission.

Stopping by briefly on an early Saturday afternoon, I'm happy to report that they are off to a good start here. The building is spacious and spare. They were a bit light on the baked goods I've come to love (especially the Wolverine and the cheese rolls - I highly recommend them if you haven't tried), but it was after the morning rush, so I wasn't surprised either.

However, it was an opportunity to try their pizza, and get something for my sweet tooth, and both made me confident that nothing that I love about these coops have changed in the newest store.

Fontina/feta cheese, mushroom, pesto pizza - 

Pizza of the day. The crust was thin and perfect texture, the cheese aromatic, mushrooms lending a subtle earthy flavor, and the thyme and basil giving it an explosion of flavor. With all the fancy places like Baretta, Flour+Water, etc. serving pizzas, I'm happy to report that purely on taste, the pizza compares well. But of course, you get one choice. (That's socialism for you. But, you know, if the one pizza is what you want, all you need is one choice.)

Chocolate mint cookie -  

Absolutely delicious. It happens to be vegan, but it's not the reason you should get them.  They had a firm (almost crispy) outer edge, and was moist inside, with chocolate slightly gooey, and just a hint of mint. It's quite rich, so sharing one with a friend is a good idea.

Valencia has become a very strollable street, and it's ideal to pick up something to eat from here.  Worried about all the organic olive oil soaked crumbs falling on you or accidentally letting a drop of fair trade coffee hit you while you walk? No worries, you are in the Mission and wearing plaid and jeans. Brush it off without skipping a step and proceed on your journey to Dolores Park.

Assuming the cheese roll and wolverines are as good as the other locations, I'd recommend them as well. To me, either with a cup of coffee is a great way to start the day, being open at 7 during the week, and 7:30 on the weekend, though they are closed on Monday, which sadly makes Monday that much more Mondayish. (though in the place, the menu on the wall says closed Tuesday instead, go figure) Check the website for breads and pizza schedules.
author: Boris C.

description: If you are craving pizza, I would go to this bakery. I came in when the special pizza of the day was mushroom and leek, and it was some of the best pizza I've ever had.
author: Jenn T.

description: What amazing pizza!! We got there right before 11:30AM on a Sunday, so we got two  slices from the very first pizza of the day, fresh out of the oven. It was perfectly crispy & the cheese was so gooey, it was everything I could have dreamed of! The flavor of the day was gorgonzola, walnuts, & arugula with a balsamic glaze, an unbeatable combination. Top that off with some of their other delicious baked goods like a fruit & chocolate scone, a pesto & feta cheese roll, & 2 cups of small coffee & you have the perfect brunch for a mere $13!
author: Lori N.

description: Stop #2 on "vacation 2013 with Sue" was another quick one. Well, quick save for the line out the door.After walking around in the Mission on a beautiful and warm day some fresh baked bread sounded really good. When doesn't it? I had the Chocolate Thing. It had the consistency of challah bread with good dark chocolate chips. I was quite satisfied.
author: Dan H.

description: I love scones but a good scone can be hard to find.  I found it at Arizmendi. They also have delicious pizza with creative toppings and an assortment of other wonderful baked good.  Yum yum yum.
author: Monica R.

description:
Oh hell yeah.

This place makes me feel like an idiot for ever considering going carb-free.  How could I live a life without that cranberry-cornmeal scone?  That cauliflower-curry roll?  The chocolate-blackberry bread pudding?  The cheese roll (which just needed a dab of cream cheese to make it beyond beyond).

I already count it as an existential loss that I went too early to snag their pizza.

Forget my juice cleanse...Nothing beats Inhaling the aroma of their self-serve stacks and stacks of pastries and cradling a precious bag of 'em to (maybe) share with loved ones.
author: Sandy C.

description: Fresh and delicious pizza, great bakery items!
author: Laleh J.

description:
Came here mid morning to try their pastries and coffee.

COFFEE was great ;)

I went a little overboard on the pastries because I wanted to try a handful of them.
I grabbed the CORN MUFFIN w/BLUEBERRIES, the CHOCOLATE THING, CINNAMON ROLL, and a SCONE.

Out of that bunch, I only enjoyed the CORN MUFFIN. The CHOCOLATE THING was terrible, I feel bad saying it and maybe its because I had Berkeley's the Cheeseboard's chocolate thing but man, its nothing like what I was expecting. The dough was bland, with dark chocolate pieces mixed in.....

I will come back and try the pizza and grab myself 10 of their corn muffins though!
author: Sunny W.

description:
This is really a 3 1/2 star review, mostly because of the pizza. 

First off, the bake goods seem great. I had a cornmeal lime cookie the other day. What the hell is a cornmeal lime cookie? It seems like an impossible combination...but, not so. Super amazing.

The pizza could be extraordinary. Really. But the dough sucks. If the pizza has been out of the oven for more than 3 minutes or so it starts getting soggy and limp. Nobody wants dough that goes limp after 3 minutes. Cmon Arizmendi! you're a bakery! Put together some real pizza dough. Your ingredients are great, the combinations are inspired, and you put it all on... limp dough. Bah. The pizza is good nonetheless, but it could be so much better.
author: Jim T.

description:
I don't even care what the pizza of the day is, I'm getting it. Just don't go on Tuesday because they aren't open. They will often combine ingredients I would never dare to try together on a pizza, vegetables I normally don't like, it doesn't matter -- always amazing. Slices are reasonably priced at $2.50.

Chocolate chip cookies are excellent and pretty darn big. I haven't even bothered to try the numerous other products on offer, though I don't see how anything from here wouldn't blow you away.

That it is a worker owned co-op in the Mission makes all of this that much better.
author: Ben M.

description:
Wanted to try the pizza here as it is supposed to be similar to Cheese Board's. 
Ingredients are good, but the combinations can be odd. 

The bad: Only ONE type of pizza per day, so if you are allergic to an ingredient you are S.O.L.  NO MEAT! Very limited seating.  The day we went we they were serving cauliflower pizza, very ambitious but the flavor didn't work and I thought the pizza was a dud.  If you're vegeterian this is a good option.

Their pizza style is most similar to California (thinner dough, no crust).  I prefer some crust on my pizza.
Is the pizza good,? yes Great? no
author: Joe G.

description:
Save for their solid chocolate chip and shortbread cookies, the half-dozen+ baked goods I've had were heavy, snoringly bland, and *gasp*... dry. (Yeah, including the popular blueberry snails, chocolate things, scones, and cheese rolls).

However, come here for inventive, fresh, ever-changing chewy crusty pizza. Arizmendi Pizzeria would be a better name...
author: Snuffles B.

description:
A wonderful place! I was on a field trip around this area, and had smelled the wonderful aroma from two blocks away. If you don't have any money, just stand in front of the bakery and take a big, long whiff of the pleasantries. 

The place itself has limited seating, about 15 seats. They sell the pizza of the day, and other baked, delicious goodies. I bought a blueberry scone, pecan roll, two chocolate chip cookies, a slice of pizza, and a arnold palmer all for 17$! What a great deal! 

Everything there was so worth it! There were so many vegan options as well. I would love to go back there again and gather up more baked goodies.

The servers were also very nice! Their service is most excellent! Everyone you deal with in this bakery is in just such a wonderful mood.

Also another plus, they take credit cards!
author: Eunice L.

description:
My new favorite bakery! Really yummy sticky buns (not too sweet... Just right!) Also the brioche & chocolate thing was really good. 

Unfortunately, not a fan of the parmesan bread.  It was too hard and a bit chewy at the same time.  Hey... I still love it here though! Nobody's perfect!
author: Lee E.

description:
Gosh I love their Honey Buttermilk buns so much! These gals were so nice one day when I was waiting for them to come out of the oven. They bypassed the shelves and went straight into my hands! I even wrote a song about them... "Honey Buttermilk Buns are one of a kind... na na... oh they taste so fine!! So Fine!!"

Now if I can only come up with a lyric for Blueberry Corn Muffins...
author: Aggie Z.

description:
Not only do they bake the most delicious breads and pastries, but amazing espresso drinks are made here too.

I have spent many, many lunch breaks walking up the street and then loitering about the bakery taking in the view of Valencia St (often I find that they play some awesome tunes).

Wonderful, friendly staff always make my day when I visit Arizmendi.
author: Hilda Z.

description:
Alright Yelpers, here's the deal...

So as a few friends and I were on our mission from Castro to Pi Bar to yelp it out, we pass by Arizmendi.  Now, I've heard about this place more than plenty and a couple of friends made some recommendations.   

During finals last semester, one of my friends brought us pizza from here and he's all, "it's from a bakery, but it's AWESOME!"  YUP! it was =)

Now my other friend kept ranting and raving about a corn cherry scone and I'm thinking, a scone with corn and cherries in it, right....BUT to my surprise, OMG...it's made with corn meal with cherries and goodness. yum yum for my tum tum.

Arizmendi you ARE the BUSINESS!
author: Edrian D.

description:
Love this bakery! 

The daily scone special is my favorite, they are not too sweet and perfect consistency.  The cookies are great too. I have never tried the pizza, but I have been meaning to for awhile. 

Cash only. 

I come here whenever I find myself in the Mission!!!
author: Julie J.

description: Excellent place and worth the line, which wasn't very long during weekdays. Wondered into this outfit while walking around the neighborhood. When you walk in, you are enveloped by the savory and sweet baking smell. I wasn't very hungry so I just got two scones, a vegan and a currant one. Boy were they good, I know I'm saying vegan scone tastes good. They were both very moist, fresh, and somehow very light. There were many other choices including lavender cookies, ginger scones, and of course tempting looking pizzas. No doubt I will return to try the other offerings very soon!
author: Charles L.

description:
chocolate thing: dry and hard to chew & swallo, don't understand what everyone raves about

blueberry corn muffin: good! this one i can eat a lot of

pizza: not bad, not great.  the day's toppings were fresh corn, feta, some peppers.  crust/dough was pretty good, but that day's toppings were pretty meh

staff wasn't that friendly but not rude by any means
author: Jeffry C.

description:
I wish this branch of the Arizmendi cooperative "chain" were better!  Having gone to pretty much all the co-ops (except the Cheese Board mothership)- I have to say that the Valencia bakery is the "least good "of the lot, not bad, just lacking.    The selection of baked good pales in comparison to the East Bay bakeries, availability is spotty, and the execution is pretty erratic. Size and consistency of their stock items varies greatly from day to day, and while I realize that baking is not a hard science at this scale, they should have it down by now, years after the Valencia store opened.  Today, about half the shelves were empty by 2pm, and it didn't look like more was coming out.

The store layout is rather unfortunate, the line for pizza blocking access to the baked goods- a problem they share with the 9ave store.
author: paul h.

description:
This location has a very nice staff, but that is to be expected from a co-op right?

Have headed to the Sunset location for years & Valencia happens to be convenient, almost too convenient to work.  

When I make my salad, sometimes I like to get their fresh olive bread for a whoppin $1.50.  It's not too big, not too small either.

Pizza of the day is $2.50 a slice and usually has creative toppings.  I see the A-frame pretty much everyday, only had it once. It was good not great but pizza isnt my lunch go-to. Clients swear by their pizza. 

I swear by their yummy vegan muffins for $2 and God knows I'm not a vegan.
author: Athena S.

description:
I had this on my S.F. must-try list for a long time before absentmindedly stumbling in on a lazy Sunday, not having planned or prepared for the mind-blowing selection of freshly baked delicacies.   Thankfully my appetite had been fully activated after a long walk through the hilly neighborhood.

Arizmendi is a worker-owned cooperative with a pervasive, unpretentious communitarian vibe.  Rather than choosing what I wanted, I narrowed my selections based on what I thought I MIGHT be able to live without...which wasn't much.  

The daily pizza selection is the foremost crowd-pleaser, and I've dutifully tried two different offerings:  artichoke and spinach, on my maiden visit, and Brussels sprouts, smoked Gouda, red chili and lemon oil on my second trip.  Both pizzas were astonishingly good, fresh, with a slightly blackened bread-like (sourdoughy?) crust.  Beyond taste, another key advantage for pizza-lovers is the by-the-slice option.

Beyond pizza, I can also heartily recommend the magically moist cheese rolls and the sinfully soft chocolate chip cookies.  The bakery prepares an assortment of sweet and savory foccacias and flatbreads, and I decided an appropriate dessert was the pear and mixed berry foccacia, topped with an oat crumble.  The bread was a little too thick to support the subtle flavor of the fruit, but it was an interesting concept and well-worth trying.  Several varieties of muffins and scones, among other more unique baked curiosities, await for subsequent visits.

Seating is limited but most people are interested in carry-out or eat-on-the-run, so I haven't had trouble securing a spot.
author: Derek W.

description:
What a pleasant surprise! So many good things to eat here...so difficult to decide. 

If you happen to choose pizza over other savory treats, be patient and wait a bit for a fresh whole pie so that you'll enjoy some very good pizza. It's fresh and relatively healthy, considering, you know, that it's still pizza. 

Regardless of what you buy, and I don't recall seeing anyone walk out of an Arizmendi empty-handed, the taste of fresh ingredients comes through in all of their items.
author: Mike H.

description:
A week ago I stopped here to grab some bread and ran into some friends. When I got back home, I realized that I was missing my credit cards. I went back to the bakery and the other places I'd been that day, but no one had them. I kept checking the transactions, but my cards weren't charged. Fast forward a week later. I walk into the bakery, ask them if they're found my cards, girl searches in the back, and lo and behold: they've found them! Moral of the story: these are good people, who didn't charge my credit cards during the week they had them. 

Pastries/bread products are good, if a bit overpriced. Their sticky bun was OK (not as good as at Flour bakery in Boston or Clear Flour Bread in Brookline). Their X-roll (cheese+corn+arugula) was like an upscale Cheez-it. $2.75 for the roll.
author: Alex K.

description: Everything here is amazing and affordable. My favorites are the corn cherry scones, blueberry corn muffins and the vegan banana nut muffins.
author: Amin S.

description: Delicious pizza and pastries. The coffee is quite good as well. One of the best places to have a quick breakfast in your way to BART or your Palo Alto bus.
author: Ato B.

description:
It's nice to know that there a places for people who still eat carbs in San Francisco.  

I'm a big fan of their more savory treats, like pizza and olive bread (with whole olives in it). There sweet treats are equally as good though. They have many vegan options, but sadly, only one gluten free option. I have a friend with Celiac (actually Celiac, not some chick that says she doesn't eat gluten *insert eye roll here*) so it's nice that she can come with me.

It's a little stressful the first few times you visit because it is serve yourself.  You want to see what's available, but more experienced shoppers can seem impatient sometimes.  Also, the service can be hit or miss sometimes ... but I don't let that inhibit my ability to enjoy the wonderful baked goods produced here.
author: Lara O.

description:
I don't care if I have a vicious allergy to wheat gluten. I will deal with the pain. This bakery is just that good. I love the one on Lake Merit just a little bit more.

The cookies are always so fresh and flavorful. The crack of the firm crusty breads reveals the most pillowy soft interiors. One everything baguette and a bit of bree is the perfect snack to take to Dolores Park or a swanky dinner affair. 

The staff always looks happy and are eager to help, and the line moves faster than you would think. The smell of the shop is just divine. Stop by and see what they have that day, as the stock is always changing and there are yummy seasonal goodies they pop up with every so often.

Also the pizza is a little pricy, but, it's not your average takeout pizza. It's not an every day kinda meal - but it's something I would eat whenever I was feeling a litte fancy.
author: Jonathan D.

description:
Chocolate cherry pecan cookie - crunchy chewy exterior and moist chocolatey deliciousness. And the size!?! Huge!

Great focaccia too.
author: Natasha I.

description: I'm gonna take a minute to talk about scones. They are heavenly. They are flakey and cakey. Their scones are full of magical sparkles and butter. Probably the best I've ever had. Ever. Even the wheat free scones are full of magic. The coffee is also worthy of pasty pairing- they serve Equator (which I think is a bit underrated). Highly recommend coming here- way better than Tartine, in my humble opinion.
author: Joyce S.

description: Love the daily pizza, best to call in and make sure they haven't sold out yet. The El Salvadorian sweet/savory muffins are delish.
author: Jay F.

description:
I really like this place even though the quasi-absence of seating and the looooong lines  are sometimes a deterrent.

PIZZA is delicious!!!!! Especially the very simple mozzarella+basil!

Pastries are good, especially the muffins. Chocolate chipotle is my favorite.
author: Eli E.

description: Just ridiculously good pizzas - don't ever change guys! These are by far the best pizzas I've ever had. I always order an extra pizza to take home and eat later.
author: Cam C.

description:
One of my most coveted rituals....Arizmendi in the morning. We've been frequenting the mission location since it's opening and since it's close to work and home, no question!

They are getting better and better at what they do, as the 9th Ave location has set a high standard for myself and others. All their goods are becoming more consistent and well, I'm hooked on my morning ritual so I don't need to  justify it further. It's also lovely to see that they establish the local mission culture and have their own items that 9th and other locations dont.....they have much more vegan options which rocks!

One thing, please, do a head to head with 9th Ave's focaccia flats....Valencia needs some help there.

I'm a huge fan for coops. And establishments that foster goodness.

My bran muffin and coffee and I'm set!

I heart you Arizmendi!
author: ERICA E.

description: Really tasty pizza here...reminds me a lot of the Cheese Board in Berkeley, as this appears to be a co-op as well, offers a single yummy pizza each day, they both have similar thin-ish flavorful crusts, and both give you an extra sliver of pizza with your order as a little bonus (or for letting your friends mooch while simultaneously inducing them to cave and buy their own).  The slice of tomato goat cheese and basil pesto I had last sunday was great, although a little greasier than what you might find at the Cheese Board.  Nevertheless, an excellent way to spend $2.50!  ($20 for a whole pie)  Must try their baked goods another time...
author: Linus W.

description:
I'm in love with this bakery.

Every single item i tried here was nothing short of amazing: 

-Cowgirl cookie $2 (Oatmeal, raisins, walnuts?, chocolate) - freakin' delicious.
-Chocolate chip cookie $2 (oooey gooey and melts in your mouth and hands)
-Slice of pizza of the day (broccolini, white cheddar, asiago, basil?, garlic oil) $2.50

Love at first bite!!!!  :::swoooooonnnnn:::
author: Jennifer C.

description:
First time to visit this bakery while in the Valencia. 

I was looking for some pastries for snack and I happen to drop by this organic produce looking place. "hmmm, interesting...," I opined to the bread selection. they had scrumptious cookies and shortbreads as well as baguettes and bialy. 

What caught my eyes was the vegan focaccia pizza. I love how colorful and well prepared they looked, so I bought some. the staff was friendly too.

As I took a bite of vegan focaccia pizza, I am quite amaze that it taste so good! the artichokes blend really well with the squash and the peppery aftertaste just leaves me wanting more!

I definitely, definitely recommend this bakery whenever you're in the Valencia or down 9th and Irving :) I wonder if they plan on opening down the financial district or SOMA area near the Embarcadero :D
author: Pierre B.

description:
Never disappointed by their bakery case..Also have good coffee. 

Chocolate chip cookies: A-mazing. Chewy, chocolaty, everything you want in a cookie and more. 

Almond macaroon: Really really good, dense, chewy,  moist and delicious. 

Coconut macaroon: Also good, but not compared to the almond one which stole the show. They should dip this one in chocolate. 

Pumpkin Muffin: Better than expected. Had this warm with butter. It is perfectly spiced with cranberries and walnuts. 

Scones: On the dry side, not their best offering. 

Lemon Curd: Wanted to like this but it had a weird aftertaste. O well, can't win them all. 

Whole wheat cheese roll: Ok if heated. Tough dough, kind of oily. 

Jalapeno Corn Cheese Bread: Good, though I am not a fan of jalapenos. 

Haven't tried their pizza but people seem to love it. Not reviewing my favorite thing here because I don't want it to sell out!
author: Oly O.

description:
Arzimendi is my weekend go-to.
They always have fresh baked, delicious, well priced breads and can satisfy both your salty, and sweet cravings.
The pricing of this place is really awesome - 2 of you can easily stuff your face for under 20$!
They have decent caffeinated drinks and their pizza is BOMB. They don't have a fixed menu for anything (except the caffeinated drinks). Walk in, pick out the breads and pastries that you want (self service) from your left, check the pizza for the day on the board, walk up to the register, order your slice, pay, stuff your face, sit back and enjoy.
NOTE: PLEASE BE COURTEOUS - DO NOT PUT YOUR GRIMY PAWS ALL OVER THE BREADS AND PASTRIES. They have wax paper and bags for a reason, so that YOU, yes YOU, the one that just got off from the BART after touching all the nasty seats, don't rub your germs all over those delicious corn muffins that are going in to my mouth.
author: Aabhas S.

description: The b-e-s-t way to open your morning! The coffee is amazing and the pastries are heaven! You have to try the carrot muffin! Yummy!
author: Yana A.

description: it's pretty awesome that Arizmendi has 1 different kind of pizza every day AND it is always vegetarian! i really appreciate that this place offers choices for vegetarians without sacrificing flavor. Make sure you try their almond pastry and pecan roll
author: Giselle C.

description:
You evil temptress, you!

Do yourself a favor and do not move near an Arizmendi. One moved near me and made the neighborhood and now serves as a salacious siren call whenever I am out (except on Tuesdays because they are closed).
author: daimian holiday s.

description: Best pizza in SF! Go all the time. So fresh, organic, affordable, made with such love.
author: Melanie H.

description:
I like making metaphors out of places. So if Arizmendi was a person, she would be a smokin' hot babe that bakes smokin' hot bread. 

No lie, this place sells the best fresh bread and pizza mine mouth hath ever tasted. Arizmendi effortlessly combines the tradition of baked goods with the modernity of straight forward food choices. Their food is fresh, dependable, unique and most importantly, delicious. How attractive is that?

May I suggest:
- A square of focaccia (vegan) (could suffice for lunch itself)
- ANY of their scones
- ANY of their rolls but mostly the wolverine
- Sourdough baguettes 

Eat your warm carb nugget on the window ledges outside like everyone else or find a bench at the park down the street.
author: liz c.

description:
Amazing choc chip cookies. 65% chocolate, 35% cookie - I don't know how they did it. The fruit scones were wonderful, moist but firm and the fruit was sharp and fresh.  The Chocolate Thing was also good: their delicious chocolate chunks mixed into a very tasty brioche.

Definitely recommend this place.  The cookies usually come out of the ovens around 3:30 or 4:00pm. I plan to make this my target arrival time.
author: Drew B.

description: That is some good pizza they have here. I wanted to try the yummy baked goods but I needed a little more to eat. The thin crust pizza is light and not overwhelming. At just $2.50 a slice, it really can't be beat. They also offer a plethora of other baked goods, hot beverages and the like. I got a soy chai with my pizza. The only thing I would worry about is that the seating is limited so if you plan on eating in, plan accordingly.
author: Amy J.

description: I like Arizmendi Bakery because it is employee owned.  The pizza is great, only $2.75 per a slice... the only downfall is the the pizza can be overly greasy.  The bakery makes a different kind of pizza every day, so it can be a surprise but it is always good.  So far, my favorite is the mushroom pasteo pizza. I really like the pizza fresh out of the oven... yummy. The scone is very tasty, and the lavender shortbread is also excellent.  On average, you will be spending about $6 for a piece of pastry and coffee.  The place is bit small so it is not the best place to hang out.  Staff are very friendly so it is a plus.
author: Evelyn W.

description:
I love the 9th Ave. Arizmendi. Their cheese scones (on Sunday mind you, the newer Thursday versions, not so much), are what I measure potential mates by. Ask me, I'll explain.

Anyway, I was excited that one was opening closer to me (only 6 miles walk RT instead of 9!), and went there soon after they opened. The cheese scones were not the same. Sometimes they were even a little spicy, though I haven't encountered that recently. But it seems that spicy ingredients are one of the trademarks of the Mission Arizmendi. Not being a lover of spicy food, this does not please me.  Many of their daily special breads and their pizzas contain spicy stuff and /or curry flavors. I generally dislike both.  So it makes me sad, because I love bread. 

I do like the "X roll" idea- their cheese roll but with a twist which changes daily. I don't like when that twist includes curry or chipotle, however. Damn.
Also good that they have a wheat free scone. I like that idea. It's pretty tasty, too.

I wish they would have the scones with chocolate chips again.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/_2_1FQO_DGzeCTky0x9DQA?select=S0FnqPQv8wSDx0jA5_gZ6w
 But seems to have gone away. Another damn.

My biggest gripe with this place? I have two: 1) They don't seem to list all the ingredients on their items, and sometimes this even extends to not knowing what they are selling. I.e. the X roll's sign is illegible and the counter person doesn't know what type of roll it is that day. and 2) The attitude. I don't know if it's because it's the Mission and they're just too cool for school or what, but it's not appealing. And to stand behind the counter chatting with coworkers when there's a big-ass line out the door and only one cashier who is slicing pizza rather than ringing up the line, well, not so fun. 

I would forego this place if my favorite Arizmendi were closer, but I don't always have the extra 45 minutes to walk the extra distance. Damn.

Oh, and to all the Mission yoga mommies taking a break from their hard day of mommy/baby yoga and shopping at Valencia boutiques- please keep your kids under control. Just because it's a bakery doesn't mean your kids should have free reign to run all over the place. It's not McDonald's playland.
Thank you.
author: Allucaneat G.

description:
I have yet to set foot in one of Arizmendi's shops.  Their goods keep coming to me.  Last week Alan stopped by the Emeryville location, bringing home a couple of slices of delicious pizza and an oatmeal scone that seemed to have a hint of maple.  We shared the scone for breakfast and it was marvelous.

Yesterday we impulsively invited Nina over to share the corn chowder Tam had made, a couple of La Bedaine entrees and the last of the Bakesale Betty's chicken pot pie.  It's what we call a pickup dinner, an assortment of unrelated items from the refrigerator which gives each of us something different to eat.  Nina had spent the day in SF w/ friends who had introduced her to a cafe and bakery.  She was unsure of the names of the places, but as soon as she mentioned the chocolate thing I knew where she had been.  In addition to the chocolate thing, she had brought a bialy and a pumpkin/chili roll as her contribution to dinner.  I cut the bialy and the roll into quarters.  The chocolate thing was too sweet to have w/ dinner.  The bialy was probably the best I've tasted, chewy rather than doughy as too many are, w/ a generous and tasty amount of caramelized onions in the central depression.  The bialy alone was worth a trip back to Arizmendi.  The roll was dense and flavorful w/ a liberal sprinkling of pumpkin seeds on the top and sides.  It carried a nice strong undercurrent of chili flavor but w/o the heat.  I'd never tasted anything like it.  We were all pleased.

By the time we finished dinner there was no room for the chocolate thing, even for dessert.  Nina refused to take half home, so it will be my breakfast this morning.  Arizmendi is an amazing place producing exceptional pastries.
author: Toni M.

description:
So I totally meant to write this as soon as I finished licking the remains of my Arizmendi spoils off my fingers.  Unfortunately, I ate myself into a carbohydrate coma...

I stopped her to pick up some breakfast on my way to work.  I had some cheesy savory pastry in mind but as I was going in, some guy was coming out with a pecan roll in his hand/mouth and a "I am having an orgasm" expression on his face.  I could smell the sex, I mean caramel, from my socially acceptable distance.  So as soon as I crossed the threshold, I lost complete control of my body and I was drawn as if by a crazy big magnet, right to the pecan rolls.  I was powerless to resist.  

But since life is about balance, I had to get something savory too.  I chose a focaccia with goat cheese, potato, and some other stuff. I'm pretty sure no more than 10 seconds elapsed between my paying for my food and taking the first bite of pecan roll.  The carameley nutty smell was completely intoxicating and the taste did not disappoint.  

I have loved everything I've had here, pizzas, vegan pastries, etc.  Welcome to the 'hood!
author: Linda L.

description:
CARB LOVE!

I bought a loaf of their unsliced honey whole wheat bread and I think it's the best wheat bread I've ever had. Best Ever. Yes, better than Acme and Beckmann's. 

What is this craziness that they only make this perfect bread on Wednesday? I went back and found different breads - there is a bread schedule http://valencia.arizmendi.coop/index.php?/bread-schedule/  and a pizza calendar. http://valencia.arizmendi.coop/index.php?/pizza-calendar/ It's a good thing I didn't go on a Tuesday because they're closed.

 I'm very excited about this bakery. And typically you can find free parking, if you don't mind walking a block or two.

There are lots of things I haven't tried here, like the pizza, scones, or anything with chocolate. *gasp* They have a lot of savory stuff here. I tried some muffins and I like the fact that they aren't as sweet as most places. The blueberry corn muffin tastes like something I would bake when I cut the sugar in a recipe - fresh, with just the right amount of sweetness. The vegan lemon poppy seed muffin is really delicious, and I'm not vegan.

You don't get the attitude, lines, and parking headache you get at Tartine. The baked goods seem less buttery and healthier than Destination Baking Company, though I still love Destination for its challah and some other decadent desserts. I'm more dazzled by Arizmendi than Noe Valley Bakery, though I haven't seen cupcakes here. Arizmendi doesn't make challah yet, but they say they have plans to in the near future.

Misses:
- The spelt bread seemed like a brick of denseness that I wouldn't buy again. 
- The corn cherry scones were too buttery for me.

I wish they made the honey whole wheat bread more frequently than just Wednesdays, since I'm not in SF every day. I'm freakin' loving the Arizmendi carbs. Just not on Tuesday.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Dear Carbs,

Why must you tempt me?? Stopped by this place for the first time sometime last month. Been going there once a week (except the week I was in Oahu) since then. Went today and got me a cheese roll, bialy, and vegan chocolate mint cookie. Yum, yum, and yum!!! =)

Yes, I have a love/hate relationship with carbs. Love them, but hate that I can easily gain weight eating too much of them...especially at night (big No No!) It's okay, I'm still on my 6-day workout schedule and watching my carb intake. At least they have vegan options and whole wheat bread/pastries. Still haven't tried their pizza, but I will soon, even if I am lactose =).
author: Neni E.

description: Stopped by Arizmendi on our way out of town to avoid the typical San Francisco airport fare....OH MY, what a great idea!  My hubby and I enjoyed the best focaccia bread I've tasted in my life!!!  It was an amazing explosion of tastes in my mouth...mushrooms,  fennel, cheese...oh my GOD it was good!  And, also had a very yummy flour less  chocolate mint cookie!  What a nice surprise stop!  I absolutely recommend this stop to anyone in the Mission -San Fran!!!!  Still dreaming about this.....
author: Deanne D.

description:
Love, love LOVE the Arizmendi in the Inner Sunset - by comparison, this one has somewhat sparse offerings.  Where are the fantastic onion biyalis?  The addictive crumble coffee cake?  

Of the rather limited selection that IS on offer, the sticky buns are a homerun, and the breads are delicious.  Daily pizzas have been scrumptious too.  Perhaps it's unfair to make the comparison - in a vacuum, the baked goods would surely rate a "4" - but the variety at the Inner Sunset location has set the bar too high.
author: Katy M.

description:
how can there be a baker's bakery in this town, in this time, that cannot figure out the gluten-free thing?  the cookies that show up will rot your teeth, so much sugar do they hold, the muffins are completely unsatisfying and leave a weird chemical taste (and sore on my tongue) and the focaccia is an oxygen-deprived brick.  PLEASE, you guys, figure this out -- there are any number of gluten-free 'flour' substitutes out there. start experimenting -- hello, you're a bakery.! see what the compe-tition is doing (check the baked goods at rainbow for starters).  there IS decent gluten-free out there and we're waiting for you to make your own, unique contribution.  you could start with pizza crust.

let's go, guys, you're way behind the curve.
author: jake d.

description: A bit hippie-ish for me. Lots of healthy, vegan options... which I dig... I mean, I'm happy for the vegans and all... but just didn't seem to place deliciousness as high in the priority list as trendiness. I don't know, just didn't really blow me away. I left empty-handed.
author: Sean B.

description: Pizza was the shizz! i mean, it wasn't cheeseboard amazing or anything but its definitely on my list. Chai tea is pretty good as well. Great for these depressing sf cold summer days.
author: Sondra E.

description: Frankly, I just like showing up not knowing what the pizza of the day will be.  It's unpredictable and often times so exotic. Price is cool . Easy lunch, and a great way to get out of cooking!  You can take a half baked pizza home.  Your family will love it.
author: sumaya g.

description: It's real dangerous for me (read: my waistline) that Arizmendi is on my commute to work now. I dream of their bialys and have exported their cherry corn scones for SF ex-pats that miss them that much. They also have tons of other great options, both vegan and veggie and they're a co-op (with a soon to come parklet!) Why would you go anywhere else?
author: Allison P.

description:
Excellent experience with Arizmendi - every time. The corn cherry scone is so Caribbean. Reminds me of Magdalena's tortas (of Mi Guayabera fame). The scone - chews fried, with the perfect greasiness though it's a baked treat. You bite and let the oiled corn grains scrub your tongue, look into the mark you left - and a whole dark (part of me wants to say black-ass) cherry jewels the sugar-dusted crescent. Prolly good with fried runny-yolked eggs, how I used to eat tortas. 

Coffee - organic, fair trade. Nice banyo. Great ingredient list on the board as you walk in. Spanish too - learn foodstuff by foodstuff.

Before I ever went there, the photo of their people on The Guardian had me crying right on Market (and 10th).

Slept in their doorway one night.
author: Alberto R.

description: This place is fantastic!  Specials vary daily and are always terrific, and make sure you come back for pizza of the day.  Staff/owners are very friendly and selection is well priced.  This location seems a little bigger than the 9th Avenue location.
author: Maximus L.

description: I tried their chocolate fudge cake and wow, its quite fudgy and dense. The frosting is just the right amount where it gives the cake some moistness but not overpoweringly so. The cake itself is rich in chocolate and one slice makes you feel like you're going to get the worst sugar high ever. But who is going to complain about that?
author: Chloe Y.

description: Good bakery, like the fact that it is a coop, lots of variety. I grabbed a corn bread muffin and it was pretty good.
author: Will D.

description: My boyfriend really liked the dark chocolate cherry and sea salt roll, and I had a good soy latte.  Food was probably closer to 4 stars.  There are only a few tables in a narrow hallway area so it felt more like a takeout place than a warm cozy cafe - docked a star for ambience.
author: Vivian W.

description: Fresh basil and feta cheese roll, warm from the oven... OH MAH GAWD!
author: Anjelika P.

description: Not only do they have delicious muffins and fabulous pizza, I LOVE THEIR COFFEE! I will stop by just for their coffee. I prefer it to any coffee shop in the area.
author: Renee T.

description:
Everything you love about Arizmendi, but not as good as the original. 
Like that younger sibling that never lives up to the eldest. 
Like having sex w/ someone new and wishing it was your ex. 

I'm not trying to hate. It's just not as good as the branch over by UCSF and it's not as good as Cheeseboard in Berkeley. 

But, it'll do b/c neither of those bakeries are reasonably close to me right now. 

In any case, Arizmendi is reasonably priced and delicious. I love (off the top of my head) their ginger molasses cookies, corn and cherry scones, cheesy muffins, and their bread. So tasty, but just not perfect. It is nice however, that they're in such a large space. You can actually sit down at a table and stretch your legs out. Quite nice.
author: Andrea L.

description:
--4.5 Stars--

OMG

Pizza here rocks!!! I love SF! My wife and I recently visited my brother in the Noe Valley and he recommended this place for some good eats.  We walked over there with high expectations and it did not let us down at all.  Whole pizza was $20.00 and it came out to be 8 big slices.  Not bad at all.

Arizmendi uses fresh ingredients that make a great tasting pizza.  Not to mention their great variety of pastries and bread....and that chocolate chip cookie...oh so good.  So if you're ever coming back from  work, drop by, get a whole pizza, eat a couple slices there and bring it back home for breakfast in the morning. Sounds like a plan right?

This is yet another place I will have to stop by the next time I'm up there.  Who knows, maybe I'll just move up there.

Happy eating and cheers!

E
author: Edmund I.

description:
Great bakery near my office. The smell of fresh baked bread/pastries always makes me want to get more than I should. 

Everything is warm and fresh. Good place to go for a cup of coffee and a morning pastry. always busy.
author: W R.

description: Amazing cookies, delicious pizza, and the people here always friendly.  It's also not overly priced which is a huge bonus for the Mission!
author: Sara P.

description:
So I've had this place bookmarked for the past year and I finally stopped in today! So glad I did. The pizza is delicious! My friend and I ordered a whole pizza for ourselves. Today's pizza of the day was: Roast Garlic and Broccalini, with Parmesan and Balsalmic Vinaigrette. 

The pizza was cut into 8 slices (~$20). It was thin crust. Usually I would get pretty sick of pizza after two slices, but I ate half of the pizza =X It was that delicious (especially when it comes out hot, mmm). I thought it was the right amount of dough although it could have used a little more broccalini in my opinion. At first we were hesitant when we read the ingredients for the pizza, but all of those ingredients put together created the perfect pizza! It had the right amount of flavor from each ingredient. You could taste the ingredients individually, which was something I appreciated. I am definitely coming back to try their other pizzas and baked goodies.
author: Melanie L.

description: I always stop at Arizmendi before class. They always have great  baked goods, quite a few vegan options, coffee and customer service. Definitely one of my favorite stops in the Mission.
author: Annie B.

description:
OMG ALERT !!!
This place is seriously 'carb-orgasmic' !!!

Pizza - 5 stars
Wolverine rolls - 5 stars
Cheese rolls - 5 stars
X rolls - 5 stars
Scones - 5 stars

Now I need a smoke! (a cigar maybe, I hate cigarettes)
author: Gregg M.

description: We always come here for our pizza fix. Their pizzas never disappoint. Yesterday's special was the mixed mushroom with Gorgonzola cheese. Yummy! Best pizza anywhere!
author: Lynn T.

description:
I am so grateful you opened and we really needed a decent bakery that doesn't specialize in expensive french pastries (tartine) or mexican breads (the rest of mission's bakeries).

I'm a HUGE FAN OF WORKER CO-OPS so I choose to spend more of my hard earned cash with you on the Valencia Corridor

I like everything you've made but I got heart spots for your Coconut Macaroons (esp the choc dippped), your vegan chocolate cookies, pumpkin muffins and I want to marry one of your Velvet Cupcakes they were that delicious.

My dream would be to see those velvet cupcakes and those coconut macaroons as more regular staples rather than holiday specialities...

Finally, you are the pizza wizards..but I still love Arnell's crust more. in fact, Arnell's is the only decent crust in all of SF! Your tomato sauce is heavenly for the pizza and I think you should bottle some this summer so we can buy it up..YUMM

you also have super sweet and extra cute employees which helps when there's a small wait in line...
author: shanestar h.

description:
Arizmendi is THE BEST BAKERY! 

I honestly don't think I have had better bread anywhere else.
author: Lauren C.

description: Came in here to try their daily pizza of the day, which tastes fairly similar to Cheeseboard in Berekeley. The pizza that day had sweet corn, pasilla peppers, feta cheese, and cilantro on it. It came with a mini bonus slice! I thought the flavors on the pizza could've been stronger and more prominent. Not usually a fan of food without meat on it :P, but this stuff is not bad.
author: Kevin N.

description: Possibly favorite pizza place.  They have one daily special (it's always vegetarian) and I'm not even vegetarian, but it's consistently SO good.  It's also very cheap (about $2.50 a slice)  To add to this it's a co-op so it's great for the people who work there and for the community, but even if it was owned by the Koch Brothers it would be my go to pizza place while in SF.
author: Teddy W.

description: This place is amazing. I went in for coffee while waiting for a friend and ended up getting some focaccia. I ended up going in for more to take home because I couldn't resist its deliciousness. It's always a great experience when I come in.
author: Rachel S.

description:
This review is only for the pastries and bread.  I haven't had any of the pizzas yet.

I'm a norm here although I have to resist the temptation of yummy carbs after coming back from yoga class just down the block.

All the pastries are really good, especially the cherry corn scone.  I think I've had at least most of the pastries here.  The bread is pretty good too although I'm surprised that they don't have a complete whole wheat bread.  They have a sourdough and a buttermilk loaf but no whole wheat! bleh.  

I haven't had the pizza yet but have been dying to try since I love Cheeseboard in Berkeley and heard it's by the same cooperative.

Bring cash, no credit/debit.  Closed on Tuesdays (RANDOM!) and I've been known to stop by on Tuesdays to be disappointed to see its closed (nnooooooo~!)
author: Kameron K.

description:
Arizmendi is a great neighborhood coop bakery. 

The muffins, scones, rolls and other goods are always fresh and delicious. The vegan items are good and do not taste like ingredients were vegan-substituted (no offense to my vegan friends). The staff is consistently friendly and welcoming. 

The only drawback is that certain items tend to be inconsistent. For example, sometimes the Cheese Roll has the perfect balance of cheese and roll, and other times it will be mostly roll with little cheese. It's still tasty, but the changes are noticeable.

Overall, though, very pleased, and glad to see a bakery of this caliber in the Mission.
author: Robert R.

description:
I just finished eating my vegan banana nut muffin and it left me wondering why I didn't buy two. This bakery has NAILED vegan muffins and cookies like no other. I'll go to Rainbow and see cookies that are more expensive and yet not half as good as the vegan mint chocolate chip cookie that they have here. 2 dollars for the best cookie that my mouth has ever had the pleasure of meeting?! HELL YES!! I also like that they keep things simple in the realm of vegan pastries. My muffin was awesome because it wasn't too small or too big and you got the right amount of everything. It was moist where it needed to be and a little crunchier around the edges. I only wish these guys were open until midnight so I could grab some goodies on my way home from work, but I totally understand that is a very unreasonable request.

I haven't tried very many of their breads (which I'm sure are amazing) since I'm always in the mood for a vegan pastry.

Arizmendi is so awesome that they make me like things I normally wouldn't try. I bought their lemon poppyseed muffin the other day because I was trying to spend over 5 dollars so I could get a discount at Rainbow and I was pleasantly surprised at how delicious it was when I typically don't go for lemon-flavored things.
author: Amanda M.

description:
The love for this place has got to be more sentimental than factual. Most of the bread I've got are tough and chewy and unmemorable. I'm sure it's got a fine cult following, but sad to say it's not my cup of tea.

I do like little shops with their own personality though, old school and quaint. It brings charm to the neighborhood, but I just can't really appreciate their creations. That's just me tho.
author: Chloe L.

description: Believe me if I could give more stars I would! I love love love this bakery, I've never had anything I didn't like therefore I'm always willing to try something new each time I'm in. San Fran has gone through some changes but Arizi's remains my favorite go-to bakery!
author: Josie C.

description: I've been on this weird tip where I'm eating dessert items before Im going to dinner. Many of these places like the ice cream parlors and bakeries close way before I'm finished with dinner. So in order to try them I scope a treat before hitting up my meal. Right before close, I grabbed a couple of shortbread cookies, ginger and coconut. Definitely tasty even though it was the end of the day. Turns out this was the way to go as the place I went for dinner didn't serve dessert. Score.
author: Kim N.

description:
Every time I walk over to Arizmendi, I hold my breath for fear that it's finally been featured on the Food Network or marked as a favorite of Anthony Bourdain. 

I have this nightmare that one day, I'll turn the corner and the line will be out the door and wrapped around the block. Thankfully, that has yet to happen. 

It's not that I don't wish Arizmendi success, but I secretly dread the day their line becomes as long as Tartine. 

Must haves include: 

Fresh Fruit Scone ($2.75) -  The fruit and combinations change daily! My favorite is the Ginger Pear scone, but I've also enjoyed Banana Chocolate, Raspberry Apple and so many more! 
Chocolate Thing ($2.50) - Think chocolate croissant but in a much less messy form. 
Pizza Slice  ($2.50) - Possibly the cheapest (not to mention most delicious) slice of pizza in the Mission. Be sure to check out their pizza calendar on their website for the latest updates!
author: Trella R.

description: They make amazing pizzas and pastries. The various blueberry pastries are all amazing because you will taste blueberry in every single bite. The mint chocolate chip cookie is perfectly balanced with both flavors, the cranberry muffins are flavorful and rich, and even my doggies can eat them, without getting sick =) . Also the coffee is delicious and does wake me up perfectly.
author: Mar L.

description:
When I found out an Arizmendi was opening up mere blocks from my apartment, I had to pinch myself.  And after an initial misstep (okay folks, this Arizmendi is closed TUESDAY, not Monday like the Sunset one), I visited for the first time last week.

I'm sure it won't be long before the lines and crowds are similar to those in the Sunset, but when I went at around 8:30a on a Friday, there were only 2 other customers in the place.  Of course the ambiance is very different, and while I didn't miss bumping into people while trying to get to the cherry corn scones, I did miss the cozier feel of the Sunset Arizmendi.

Nostalgia aside, the cherry corn scone was delicious.  I also bought a cheese roll and baguette piece for later, and both were comparable to what I've purchased before in the Sunset.

I'll have to return to try their pizza, and of course do my (ahem) civic duty to test their consistency with the cherry corn scones.  Don't all thank me at once.
author: Pam M.

description: The owners were very kind and the goods are consistently delicious. Also the pizza is superb and they are open early enough to go before work!! Great neighborhood bakery :-)
author: Julie P.

description: This bakery is A M A Z I N G! I stopped there after seeing the sign outside saying they had fresh baked "Walnut Bread" (tip: Sundays and Wednesdays only). I fell in love with that bread! Since then I've tried different pastries and breads. I love their muffins, my favorite is the blueberry corn one, PERFECT! So far no disappointments, one of my favorite bakeries in town. If you are a foodie you must stop here! You won't regret it!
author: Natalia Q.

description:
If you read any SF blog, then you knew Arizmendi had finally arrived in the Mission! I could only hear praises and love for the new bakery on Valencia. I'm looking forward to trying each and everything they have to offer. Though my choices haven't been mind-blowing (yet), I still wouldn't deny a pizza or chocolate thing from Arizmendi. Yum! 

Curry & Cheese Bread ---- I have my eyes on you. ;)
author: Lisa T.

description: For delicious and reasonably-priced baked goods you cannot beat Arizmendi Bakery. I like to get a City Sourdough to eat with a salad and soup for dinner, and the Corn and Cherry Scones are always welcome at the breakfast table.
author: Barney C.

description:
I was taking a stroll down Valencia yesterday when I wandered into you, randomly.  You looked sweetly innocent - I like that.   I was just poking around, but also sort of hungry and curious and you offered pizza, something with drizzled olive oil.  I indulged for $2.50.

Good god.  Sweet sweet heaven, I realized somewhere on 24th, as my eyes rolled back biting into my pizza-to-go.  Suddenly alarmed, it occurred to me I had no idea what your name was.  Something-bakery.  Azzah-something? Azar ... mari ... damn!

Arriving back home I google-map stalked you like a creeper, street-viewing back and forth along Valencia but finding only a desolate-looking garage.  You don't exist on Google!

I finally found you on Yelp, where you'll remain my little secret.  5 stars for your pizza.  If your other assortment of baked goods are anything as good, I'll be taking you home with me frequently.
author: Chris H.

description:
Thank God the mission finally has an Arizmendi! It's just as delicious as the one on lakeshore and the one on 9th ave. 
I am always done to try their specialty pizzas- always something new and with a twist! It's a perfect place to get fresh baked breads and treats.
Try the daliy pizza!!! You will not regret it!!
author: C. M.

description:
I heart Arizmendi. My family has been going to the one in Oakland forever, so when I found out one was opening down the street from my house in the city, I couldn't have been happier. 

The daily pizza by the slice is always good and the fresh baked bread and pastries make me feel like I'm in Europe. Such a treat, and a welcome addition to the other bakeries in The Mission. Great prices too! 

That loaf of bread may not look huge, but take it home and slice it up....for $3 you get 7-8 hefty slices of quality bread my friends!
author: Shira O.

description:
Jeeze! They have a pizza calendar, need I say more?!

Ok then - the service is what you would expect, not super sweet but knowledgeable and easy going. The space is light at airy making for a nice wait in line. A lot of the goods are pick your own out. Don't go there expecting the inner sunset sister, but enjoy the tasty treats such as daily pizza or fresh pastry with a chai and then take a baguette home for later.
author: Kate M.

description:
Mmm... baked goods. Best things to get:

"Chocolate thing"
Berry muffin (*better than the scone)
Cheese roll
Brioche

And, it really is not that expensive!
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
All their baked goods I have tried have been delicious.

A few days ago I ordered their pizza.  

Since it is a bakery, I expected the crust to be good.  It exceeded my expectations the crust was the best I have had in a long time.  Just the right texture, thickness, & flavor.  The real surprise was how they topped it off.  The feta cheese tasted homemade & fresh.  The pesto sauce was flavorful without being overwhelming. 

They only offer 1 flavor of pizza daily, and different locations make different flavors so call the location to ensure they have a flavor you will like.

The pesto pizza was from their Valencia St. location.  The 9th Ave. location was offering a special Chinese lunar new year pizza with baby bok choy, mixed mushrooms, sesame-ginger-garlic vinaigrette.
author: Saul M.

description: Excellent bakery with good prices. Staff isn't always the most friendly, but no surprise there since it is employee owned and relatively hip.
author: Paddy M.

description: Best scones I've ever had! Plenty of fresh fruit and at a great price.
author: Tonie F.

description:
Carbivore Crackhouse!

Like all my Mission 'hoodies, I'm thrilled that the Olive and Provolone bread is now being baked miles closer to my mouth as I roll out of bed on Wednesdays. It's today's special. Ariz*mmm*mendi offers daily specialties along with a set of everyday staples of crack, I mean, breads, pizzas and other baked goods. 

Though they've been teasing me and my Valencia Street fellows for weeks with tiny samples (just like the dealers do), today marks their official Grand Opening with a fanfare of balloons and signage beckoning you to enter and explore the mixed menu of sweet and savory treats. As if it's even necessary to do anything more than open those gorgeous glass front doors and send wafts of their pizza oven aromas into the street. 

$4 bucks for a Cherry Corn Scone and two mini-loaves of my favorite SF bread (sourdoughwhat?). Look out, Tartine. A new line is forming down here.
author: jaime c.

description:
Ok so I honestly just walked in to use their facilities but thought i would take something small with me to go. Without thinking I grabbed a currant scone and I believe a ginger one? (haven't had it yet). But I am enjoying my currant scone now and well... absolutely AMAZING. The woman in front of me got a slice of pizza to go and I will for SURE be giving that a try on my next return visit. 

These ladies really know what they're doing, I had passed by a few times throughout the day and everything in the cases looked so delicious.

Thank YOU!
author: Penelope B.

description:
Pizza was good, but my expectations were higher. I'm sold on the Cheeseboard concept of having only one pizza on the menu that changes daily, with local organic ingredients. My disappointment is directed at the crust. I'm just not a big fan of Arizmendi's pizza crust. I remember Cheeseboard's crust being much, much better- thinner and tastier. 

I'll have to give it a second shot. I love artisan pizzas and the minimal commitment that comes with ordering by the slice.
author: Lily L.

description:
Pizza: Good, but not as good as Cheeseboard. It's artisan-style, organic, thin-crust, with one pizza type offered daily.  The flavors are good but the crust is a little on the tough side.  Also, when you order pizza by the slice, you get an extra sliver to nibble on -- but not when you order a whole pizza. Huh?

Baked goods:  Every baked good I've gotten from Arizmendi has been "okay," but rather dense and tough.  The selection is along the lines of hearty muffins, scones, pecan roll, and random cheese-knots -- no croissants.

Coffee & Service: Good.

Conclusion: I stop by for a slice of pizza on my way home from work, but only because it's on the way.
author: Jen R.

description:
I try to periodically bring in assortments of pastries for the coworkers from new or notable places around town. The pastries at Arizmendi are self-serve which is nice when you're mulling things over or not quite sure what you want. 

I went with two cheese rolls and two x rolls for the savory people. Two corn and cherry scones, a currant scone, 3 chocolate things, a brioche knot, and 3 sticky pecan rolls filled things out on the sweet end of the spectrum. Most of the pastries were still warm but I was a little apprehensive b/c they felt quite weighty and dense. Overall, we were all very pleased with the assortment. The bread on the chocolate thing was so airy and fluffy, quite delicious despite it's humble appearance. The scones were crumbly without being heavy or dry and I was happy that nothing was too saccharine sweet. 

I'll be stopping by again for bread  and pizza too. Goes without saying that  I eat up their whole schtick about local/organic ingredients and co-op strategy. Arizmendi is a great addition to the neighborhood!
author: Candice L.

description:
Summary: Good interesting baked goods, not a place to chill though.

Tried a few things here: fig fennel roll, ricciarelli (Italian almond cookie), and a bite of their pizza.

Fig fennel roll had a really hard thick crust, which I actually like, but I could see it turning some people off.

Ricciarelli was fantastic. Crispy on the outside, soft and moist in the middle. My first (and definitely not my last) time trying one.

Pizza was just ok.

Not much seating, just a few small tables.
author: Gary Y.

description:
Came here to refuel after a long hike.  

Love: jalapeno cheddar seeded breadstick.  

Like: choc chip cookie

Highly Dislike: mocha bread pudding.  This was dense and dry.  

Okay: wheat free focaccia.  texture like cornbread, not bread.
author: T Y.

description: Great vegetarian pizza as well as breakfast muffins/scones/etc., plus various coffees and chai -- everything is yummy! If you go here, you can't go wrong.
author: Molly P.

description: Good selection of self-service baked goods - breads, muffins, a few pastries. I go here every couple of days on my way downtown from the Mission for their vegan goodies. The lemon poppyseed muffins are OUTSTANDING. I've had a few other selections as well - vegan focaccia (not the greatest), vegan spelt zucchini muffin (pretty good), and berry vegan scones (great!) The service is quick and friendly, and it's easy to pick something up in a bag and eat it on the way to BART just down the street.
author: Kathryn P.

description: LOVE this place.  Funny, with so many pizza slice options in the Mission (Escape, Airnell, Serrano's, etc.)  Arizmendi is becoming my fave and it's meatless (and I'm usually a pepperoni or sausage guy.)  The baked goods are great too.  Lots of seating if you want to take in a snack and a cup of coffee.  You can experience lines in the morning or late afternoon, but it's worth it.  Again on the pizza, there's a different flavor everyday, but all of 'em that I've experienced have been delicious!
author: Richie W.

description:
My love affair with odd pizza toppings began when I was 15 and I had my first slice of red potato and feta pizza at the Arizmendi location on Lakeshore in Oakland. 

Anytime I'm on Lakeshore, I have to get a slice. Unfortunately the Inner Sunset location is way too far for me to go to for a slice of hipster pizza. I reserve my Inner Sunset trips for San Tung dried fried beef. 

Now that there is a Mission location (Yay!!) I can hop on BART or take a stroll through Hipsterdom on a nice day for a slice of argula, artichoke hearts, basil pesto, sundried tomato etc etc pizza.

Mmmmmm. I wish I had a slice right now.
author: Kiristen R.

description: I have gone to Arizmendi for pizza at several locations, mostly at the Irving St bakery. The pizza varies between good to OK. Today on the way home, I stopped by the Valencia store and bought three slices to share with a friend. When I got my pizza i was not happy because it was way overcooked, but as we were hungry and I do not like to complain, I ate one piece, but it was so bad I  brought back the other two pieces and asked for ones that were not burnt, I was  then  told" they look good to me". I said, I strongly disagree and would like two other slices which were cooked OK but they still were not very good. I will pass on this shop in the future.
author: Cary F.

description:
the fig fennel roll is amazing. 

today i got the fig fennel roll, walked a block, consumed my roll like a rabid beast, then actually went back (in the pouring rain, sans umbrella) to get another. that i ate within two blocks.

sad was the day (a saturday) that i visited and the fig fennel wasn't available.  you must go on a sunday to have it.

the place is cute, always well lit and cheery. very few seats - it's not really meant for groups or reading a book or doing work on a laptop.
author: cecilia y.

description:
Their pizza is my favorite cheap weekday lunch. I swing by here about once a week. Figured I'd get sick of it if I went more often than that. It's pretty much identical to the pizza at their Inner Sunset location. Artichoke anything is the best. 

Some things are better here than their Inner Sunset location. They have a large selection of morning pastries and pastries are priced with a flat rate instead of by the pound. It's more practical than having a limited amount of cash and trying to figure out how many muffins I can afford since I have no idea how much muffins weigh.

Though this location is more efficient, I like the atmosphere at the Inner Sunset one more. This location feels cold and sterile and there's no outdoor seating even though there's room for it.
author: Victoria N.

description: While on vacation we stumbled across this place and with a line out the door, decided we had to try it.  The line moves fast and it's cash only.  All of the bakery items looked delicious and we settled on some focaccia bread.  I REALLY wish I would've checked out all the Yelp reviews first and done my homework while waiting in line.  The focaccia was tasty, but not anything to write home about.  I felt like I got the short end of the stick when I finally read up on Arizmendi and realized we should've ordered the pizza, chocolate chip cookies and scones.  Drats.  Next time we're in town though, I'll know what to order and won't panic being overwhelmed with all the options.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Sidenote: I signed up for Yelp just to rate this place.

I lived in Berkeley for a summer and experienced the magic that Cheeseboard.. now that I live in the Mission, I still crave it.. but obviously, it's far (like, across the bay far).

Found this place on Yelp, and OH MY GOD. Co-op, daily vegetarian pizza, crazydelicious? It's like a Cheeseboard that's 4 blocks away instead of 40 miles! Plus, they have baked goods. I tried their cheese curry roll? DELICIOUS. 

Amazing. I have a pizza place in the Mission now =)
author: Trisha Q.

description:
Bread is mediocre.

Chocolate thing is their saving grace.
author: Jack K.

description: Love this place - it's near our house, so we can run over there and get an amazing loaf of whole wheat sourdough or their bread sticks!  The pizza and pastries are great, too.  The line moves slowly when it's busy and some people (like my impatient husband from New Jersey) complain about it - I just enjoy smelling the fresh baked goods and take some deep breaths and think about how grateful I am that this place is here...
author: Steve H.

description: The surprise rockstar here is the Pizza!! Thin crust pizza is just right and the toppings are fresh (love the artichoke). The scones and breads are excellent, but when nearby on the weekend, go for the pizza!
author: michael p.

description: Tried four whet free goodies and they were all awesome! It's a bit more expensive but that's to be expected with gluten free stuff. I will be going back for more! Great customer service as well!
author: Marni S.

description:
Misleading three stars.

I'm not yelping the bread, the granola, the cookies or the pizza. That five star yelp is here: http://www.yelp.com/biz/arizmendi-bakery-san-francisco#hrid:futxGUNUyNkVlXYqkH4h8g

Today was for coffee so I could check out the new space. Coffee was fine. Venue seems bigger than the Sunset location. Everyone, from the employees to the customers, seemed happy to be there.

Left hoping there will be a third location. I want a reason to give the bread, the granola, the cookies and the pizza another round.
author: Jason B.

description: One word: Pizza. Or maybe nine words: Summer squash, lemon zest, ricotta, parmesan, and parsley pizza.
